intro: Almost every part of our body seems to be the subject of endless debate. But there’s one part you don’t hear much about - the chin. Join Rob and Neil as they investigate this forgotten part of our face and explain some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: How long ago do you think humans developed chins? Was it...
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: something that sticks out from a surface
people related to us from a long time ago
talk with friends in a relaxed way

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. Hello.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hi there, Neil. Hardly a day goes by without hearing someone talking about some aspect of our bodies. Do you know what I mean, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, yes, Rob. Almost every part of our anatomy seems to be the subject of endless debate. It could be our stomachs and what we eat. It could be our posture and how we stand. It could be our skin and how we should look after it.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, I know, it gets very tedious – that means boring – so I don't really take any notice, as you can see! But there’s one part of our body you don’t hear much about – and that is the chin.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The chin? You mean the small bit of bone under the mouth? It’s not the most interesting part, is it Rob? I mean, it doesn’t do anything, does it? I must admit I’ve never even thought about it. What’s it for, anyway?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, some people think it’s very useful for folding up large sheets and towels. You know, you hold one end under your chin like that with it…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Come on, Rob, you're not being serious!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Of course not. But seriously, the more you think about it, the more interesting the chin becomes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You’ve still got to convince me, Rob. A chin is just a chin. That’s all there is to it.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Not so fast, Neil.  The chin may turn out to be a more important part of the body than you think. But before we get into that, let’s turn to the quiz. Chin up , Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A good phrase - it means stay positive and optimistic.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK well how optimistic are you about getting this question right? How long ago do you think humans developed chins? Was it...

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hmm. I have no idea. They all sound far-fetched to me. Far-fetched means something is difficult to believe. But I think I’ll go for 2 million years ago.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: 'B'. Okay. Well, we'll find out if you're right or wrong later on. But the first thing to say is that humans are the only animals to have developed a chin. Let’s listen to Dr James Pampush from the University of Florida. What word does he use to mean it sticks out?

transcript.author: Dr James Pampush from the Department of Anthropology at the University of Florida
transcript.text: Humans are the only animal that have a chin and by that I mean, you have this bony projection underneath your teeth that sticks out past your teeth on the lower portion of your jaw and it’s such an unusual feature, that in a way it sort of helps define what it means to be human.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So he used the word projection which means something that sticks out from the main surface.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And the word jaw is used to describe the lower part of the face, which the chin is part of. So, we now know exactly what the chin is. But why did it develop?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now from what I understand, Rob, it has a lot to do with when humans started to cook their food, so the food they ate became much softer. Therefore, our ancestors – that’s the people related to us from a long time ago – they didn’t need powerful jaws or sharp teeth anymore. And, strangely, that made the jaw drop and produced that odd piece of bone we know as the chin.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But some time later the chin became associated with sexual attraction in men. Males with prominent – that means easy to see - jaws were supposed to be attractive to women. And men with small chins were thought to be unattractive or weak people. They were even called chinless wonders sometimes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Chinless wonder, an interesting phrase! So, let’s have a look at yours, Rob. Are you a chinless wonder? Mmm. Looks pretty normal to me. How about mine?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, Neil, your chin is rather pointed if you don’t mind me saying. But I’m not sure what that means, to be honest. So, let’s move swiftly on. Let's hear what Dr Pampush has to say about this. He uses a word that means this theory is likely to be true.

transcript.author: Dr James Pampush from the Department of Anthropology at the University of Florida
transcript.text: It seems plausible to me that chins emerged as some kind of feature and then later were selected to be sex ornaments. But not the presence of the chin but, rather, the shape of the chin being some kind of marker for sexual identity.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The word he used was plausible meaning something that is acceptable or believable.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: The word chin has also given us some interesting expressions. A double chin , for example, describes loose skin hanging beneath the chin which makes people look like they’ve got two chins! It’s something that people don’t like and often try to get rid of.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And then there’s the verb to chinwag . That means to talk a lot or to chat in a relaxed way with friends. A chinwag tends to be a conversation about things that aren't very important – but our conversation about chins is very important!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I guess so Neil, OK – so how about the answer to that question I asked you earlier? I asked you how long ago did humans develop chins? Was it a) 150,000 years ago? b) 2 million years ago or c) 5 million years ago?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said 2 million years ago.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: You know your chins, you were right. Well done!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ah brilliant!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Chins really have been around for a long time. Now, before we go, it’s time to remind ourselves of some of the vocabulary that we’ve heard today. Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: tedious

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Thanks Neil. Well, that brings us to the end of today's 6 Minute English. We hope you’ve enjoyed the programme. You can hear plenty more on our website at bbclearningenglish.com . Please join us again soon. Bye bye.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye.

authors: Dr James Pampush from the Department of Anthropology at the University of Florida
